data.title: A breakdown of Montana Grizzliesâ€™ wide receivers before the 2024 season
data.meta_description: Bobby Hauck, Aaron Fontes and Ryan Simpson break down this year's group of wide receivers.
data.text:
MISSOULA â€” The "Waffle House" boys are back in business and looking to serve up an even more delicious sequel with the Montana football team.

The Grizzlies return all six wide receivers on the 2023 depth chart and 100% of their wideout production from last season. Simply put: They're stacked.

"Everybody knows that the defense is kind of our strong suit," senior wide receiver Aaron Fontes said Wednesday. "But especially after last year coming into this year we know that our offense is going to be a lot better. Thatâ€™s definitely talking with our wide receiver corps. We got a lot of talent. Starters to backups, we could put anybody in that we know thatâ€™s reliable."

Fontes, Junior Bergen and Keelan White enter their senior season headlining that loaded receiver room. They combined for 161 catches, 2,206 yards and 14 touchdowns last year.

How much more is out there for the receivers to achieve?

"I feel like thereâ€™s a hell of a lot, excuse my language, but thereâ€™s definitely a hell of a lot," Fontes said. "With having those quarterbacks, Logan (Fife) and (Keali'i) Ah Yat, itâ€™s just good having two dual quarterbacks like that, that we could build chemistry with over the summer, which we did great with.

"Over the past years, this was definitely our year where we got a lot of good work with the quarterbacks, did some extra time with. Even with myself, I feel like Iâ€™ve definitely progressed in a way where I'm stepping up as a leader and doing just a little more just to get better."

Building upon a strong receiving year last season means melding with a new starting quarterback. Having a stable of receivers could be a benefit to whoever earns the job between Ah Yat, Fife and Kaden Huot.

"It felt good having a whole summer with all the quarterbacks coming back and all the receivers," senior wide receiver Ryan Simpson said. "Just building great chemistry on and off the field is letting us elevate. Now weâ€™re comfortable with each other coming into camp instead of just starting off at camp and going from there."

Even with all three starting receivers back, the Griz have all three backups from last year trying to earn more playing time themselves. Then there are other returners and newcomers who are fighting to crack the rotation.

"I think we have good players at wideout," Montana head coach Bobby Hauck said. "I like those guys. I think some of the young guys are improving. Whether they can push the older guys or not, weâ€™ll see. But weâ€™ve got potential for a lot of production in that group."

Who's back

Junior Bergen (5-11, 184), a senior from Billings, was named an All-Big Sky first-team wide receiver for the first time last season and was a second-team All-American all-purpose player. He totaled 59 catches for 791 yards and five touchdowns, all career highs, in 15 games in 2023. He ranked fourth in the Big Sky in catches, fifth in receiving yards and fifth in touchdown catches. As he took the next steps as a receiver, he ran just six times for 40 yards, both career lows. He ended up playing in every game in a season for the first time. He's up to 97 receptions for 1,235 yards and 10 touchdowns in 38 games.

Senior Keelan White (6-2, 184) was named Montana's offensive MVP in 2023 as he put together a breakout season. He hauled in 54 receptions for 798 yards, both career highs, and four touchdowns. He ranked fourth in the Big Sky in receiving yards and fifth in catches. He's up for 104 catches for 1,234 yards and 10 touchdowns across 44 games played and 29 starts. He had a career-best five touchdown catches in 2022.

Senior Aaron Fontes (6-1, 170) is also coming off a career season in 2023. He caught 48 passes for 617 yards and five touchdowns in 14 games while starting 13 times. He ranked 11th in the Big Sky in receiving yards. He also had 14 rushes for 25 yards last year, both career highs. He first broke out in 2022 and now has 85 grabs for 1,011 yards and seven scores in 33 career games.

Fontes knows that he has to go out and earn his playing time again.

"With competitiveness and all the vets there, yeah, we know if one of us messes up in the back of our head itâ€™s like, I know I canâ€™t be on this too much or my spotâ€™s going to get taken," he said. "But at the end of the day I know that dude right behind me is going to get me right, help me out and vice-versa.

"Even if I do get my spot taken, Iâ€™m going to try my best to get back right there. But whoeverâ€™s in front of me, Iâ€™m going to make sure theyâ€™re right as well."

Senior Sawyer Racanelli (6-3, 208) was named the team's "most inspirational player" last year as he became a contributor after two ACL surgeries, the second of which forced him to miss the 2022 season. He started twice and played in all 15 games last year, catching 10 passes for 130 yards and one touchdown. He had transferred to UM in 2022 after playing in 13 games on special teams at Washington in 2020 and 2021.

Senior Ryan Simpson (6-6, 209) of Bozeman has been a backup ever since he redshirted in 2019. He has played in 34 games, catching 35 passes for 476 yards and two touchdowns. He managed two catches for 23 yards last year. He had career highs in receptions (19) and yards (247) in 2021 and TDs (two) in 2022.

Simpson is gearing up for his final season in a competitive position group for a team that made the FCS national title game last year.

"It's very competitive, especially with a lot of vets," he said. "We know what it takes to get to that final game in January, so we all need to keep each other to that standard and being accountable for each other. Itâ€™s always competitive, but at the end of the day, weâ€™re always going to help each other improve."

Junior Drew Deck (5-9, 160) of Kalispell has appeared in 22 games off the bench going back to spring 2021. He has grabbed nine passes for 67 yards.

As for Hauck's evaluation of Racanelli, Simpson and Deck: "Theyâ€™ve done a good job. Sawyer didnâ€™t get much for spring ball and neither did Deck. They had some injury issues. But besides that, theyâ€™ve done a good job. Theyâ€™re fighting for playing time. Theyâ€™ll all play. We roll guys pretty liberally at those positions certainly, so all those guys will play a lot."

Sophomore Drew Klumph (5-11, 181) of Missoula played in three games last year but did not record any stats after he switched to receiver from defensive back. He redshirted in 2021.

Sophomore Ian Finch (6-3, 204) of Missoula has not yet appeared in a game as he enters his third season. He redshirted in 2022 and did not get in a game last year.

"Drew Klumph has done a nice job, so heâ€™s fighting for playing time," Hauck said. "Finch is fighting for playing time. Then the young guys are all scraping to get in the mix."

Junior Brady Lang (6-1, 179) of Bozeman has played in three games over three years in Missoula. He has caught two passes for 23 yards.

Sophomore Sam Alford (6-3, 186) has yet to appear in a game as he heads into his third year. He redshirted in 2022 and did not play last year as he recovered from an injury.

Freshmen Cameron Gurnsey (6-0, 181) of Butte and Jordan Dever (6-0, 171) both redshirted last season and did not appear in a game.

Who's new

Junior BJ Phillips (5-9, 150) was officially added to the roster during fall camp. He walked on with the Griz late last season and redshirted while he worked with the scout team. He spent 2022 at Santa Barbara Community College, catching 24 passes for 244 yards and two touchdowns in 10 games. He was at NCAA Division II Southwest Minnesota State in 2021, grabbing 18 passes for 216 yards and one touchdown in 11 games.

Junior Dayton Toney (6-1, 191) was also added to the roster in fall camp after he walked on in the spring and earned a spot on the team. He spent the past two years at Incarnate Word, where he caught two passes for 21 yards while playing in one game. He spent 2020 and 2021 at Hawaii, playing in three games. Toney was teammates with Griz linebacker Riley Wilson at Hawaii and at Prestonwood Christian Academy in Texas.

Montana has added three freshmen out of high school: Lekeldrick Bridges 5-11, 162), Brooks Davis (6-0, 168) and Monte Gillman (5-8, 153). Gillman, the younger brother of running back Eli Gillman, is listed as an "athlete" on the roster but has been practicing with the receivers.

Who's gone

Montana lost only two receivers from last year, both reserve players. The Griz had no seniors among their wideouts last season.

Nick Williams transferred to Alabama State, an FCS team in the SWAC. He totaled three catches for 38 yards in six games over three years in Missoula.

Lucas Prendergast has not announced a new destination since he entered the transfer portal. He didn't play in any games in 2023 at UM after he transferred from Nevada.

Frank Gogola is the Senior Sports Reporter at the Missoulian and 406 MT Sports. Follow him on X @FrankGogola or email him at frank.gogola@406mtsports.com.
